data.title: New line at EOF
data.body: When saving something, Atom adds a new line at the end of each file. How can I disable/overwrite this 'feature'?

data.title: How to build an Atom package with the Fedora 21 Dockerfile?
data.body:
Hi,

I am just wondering how one uses the Dockerfile in this repo's top-level repository to build an rpm package. I have tried running:

``` bash
docker build .
```

and (the output of the following command is [here](http://paste2.org/pe2Z096K)):

``` bash
docker build -t atom .
```

in the beta branch of this repo and neither managed to create an rpm package in the Atom source directory, or in its parent directory, or in my /tmp directory, or in the Atom directory of the Docker container. Despite this neither command returned any errors. Is the RPM package somewhere else? 

Thanks for your time,
Brenton

data.title: Atom, freezes, hangs, when large 1 line of code (minified) file is opened.
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [yes] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [yes] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [no] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [no] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [yes] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [yes] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Atom, freezes, hangs, when large 1 line of code (minified) file is opened. Could be similar to #10769.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Just open any large 1 line minified file (js, css, json etc.). Using Mac, all latest updates and the latest version of Atom. This issue was reproducible for many versions in the past and till now. PC has the same issue.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

data.title: Autodetect does not recognize the ISO-8859-1 encoding correctly
data.body:
### Description

Autodetect does not recognize the ISO-8859-1 encoding correctly, is showing how ibm855 or windows 1251.

I know that there is a detection problem of how the encoding table is checked and it is not 100% safe.

I suggest changing the way the auto-detection work, allowing to put a list of preferred character sets during automatic detection. Many projects differ only between UTF-8 and ISO-5598-1, allowing just put the two for automatic detection helps quite a lot.

That way you can put lipstick on the direction to detect all projects that use the programmer without having to change or set up every time.

Allowing put comma separated encoding which must support is a good start, as is the ignored names.

![](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Webysther/sample.atom.encoding/master/printscreen.png)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Copy sample file on [zip of repo](https://github.com/Webysther/sample.atom.encoding)
2. Open on Atom and force autodetect

**Expected behavior:** Detect ISO-8859-1

**Actual behavior:** Detect Windows 1251
### Versions

1.5.3

data.title: System for managing focus within the workspace
data.body:
Thoughts aren't fully formed on this yet, but just thought I'd jot down some things and start a conversation.

Currently there is a blue bar (in the One UI themes) that indicates
- which tab corresponds to the active pane item
- that the tree-view has focus

As we add features and integrations that utilize our panel system, we'll want to make it clear which part of the workspace has focus so that our users can quickly identify where they are and act accordingly. Thereby avoiding unexpected behavior, like when [this user](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8102) almost accidentally deleted a file in tree-view when trying to delete text in an editor.

Currently when switching focus from an editor to tree-view there are two blue bars indicating focus:
![screen_shot_2016-02-19_at_3_50_05_pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7910250/13192472/304cd76c-d721-11e5-88b5-1ab75cc1e4c2.png)
Ideally, when the focus is outside of the editor the tab blue bar would disappear.

@maxbrunsfeld and I discussed the notion of an optional **active panel** and introducing a Workspace API for activating a panel to model the fact that a panel is focused and not the panes. The tabs package would not show the blue bar when there is an active panel.

Alternatively, we could go with a DOM-based solution implemented in the tabs package where we check if the active element is in the active pane. If not, then we don't show the blue bar.

I'm leaning towards adding a Workspace API for activating a panel and baking this concept into our Workspace model. It's more explicit and could be a good feature especially considering that panels will likely come more into play as integrations are added to Atom.

Interested in your thoughts @atom/core. Thanks!

data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?

- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

When saving a file after the first time, Atom throws an UNKNOWN error:

```
Unable to save file 'C:\Users\username\Documents\GitHub\markdown-preview\lib\markdown-preview-view.coffee'
UNKNOWN: unknown error, open 'C:\Users\username\Documents\GitHub\markdown-preview\lib\markdown-preview-view.coffee'
```
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open file
2. Save for the first time
3. Save for the second time

**Expected behavior:** File to save successfully each time

**Actual behavior:** The file saves on the first time but on subsequent tries throws the above UNKNOWN error until the computer is restarted.  The backups of the original file get successfully created.

Additional info: After the initial save, it seems like Atom locks the file, and any other programs are unable to save either.  Notepad++ will error on attempting to save _until Atom is closed_, at which point it will be able to save the file.  This started happening Saturday.
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
'ELSE' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.

Atom    : 1.7.0-dev-e39d200
Electron: 0.36.7
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

(Also note the ELSE error, which I'll be reporting separately shortly after this)

data.title: BufferedProcess: search only new data for new lines rather than entire buffer
data.body:
I've noticed for some time that viewing installed packages inside of settings-view was very slow. I did a little research on it, and reported the issue on the settings-view repo here atom/settings-view#734. It seems the issue is due to BufferedProcess trying to find new lines on the entire stream buffer, including data that it's already searched for new lines on. 

This PR fixes that by only searching the new data from the stream. Viewing installed packages is now significantly faster. I've attached a before and after screenshot of the CPU profile when opening settings-view and then going to the Packages tab.
### Before

![screen shot 2016-02-22 at 3 24 51 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1184341/13231590/917f5312-d978-11e5-9488-eb51ea4f459b.png)
### After:

![screen shot 2016-02-22 at 3 25 30 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1184341/13231594/955bcad8-d978-11e5-8b24-fbf5b4169ef3.png)

### Description

This would allow a checking/verification of the downloaded artifact.
### Steps to Reproduce

2. Select a download

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

I'd love to confirm that the downloaded contents is the same as the one that was published. 
Other big organizations such as Apache Software Foundation provide signatures, while other just print md5-hashes. 
These could be integrated into the webpage or provided upon download as

```
atom-amd64.deb.md5
```

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

You just download a versionless "potentially" insecure file that is installed with root privileges.

1.5.1

data.title: Faster state serialization
data.body:
Last week we discovered with @kuychaco that serializing state is taxing on Atom's responsiveness, because serialization happens on the main thread. As per https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=536620, we discovered that structured clone isn't very performant and therefore we started researching a different approach that could perform better.

Below you can take a look at a profile of `saveState` and `IndexedDb.put()`:

![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13218622/135896a4-d96b-11e5-84b1-57eef4b94b74.png)

**Total:** `~ 116ms` for inserting 11 characters on 200 cursors.

We decided to attack the problem in two ways:
1. Use `JSON.stringify` instead of structured clone to store state in IndexedDb.
2. Defer work until a `requestIdleCallback` is dispatched. This allows to avoid blocking the main thread if some important operation is being performed.

For the same scenario, this is how this PR performs:

![after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13218818/3aeeae00-d96c-11e5-8112-9812b6fd0195.png)

**Total:** `~ 40ms`, `~ 3x` faster. :racehorse:
#### Serializing History

Another problem we noticed is that the more edits get performed on a certain buffer the slower serializing its history becomes. This makes sense, especially in the context of large multi-cursor operations, where a single checkpoint in history could contain lots of changes. 

![history](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/13219700/fa7c2220-d971-11e5-91c9-ca34289e5e19.png)

**Total:** `~ 130ms`, for inserting 5 characters on 1500 cursors.

This is an issue we still have to solve, but here's a list of potential solutions:
1. Remove history serialization altogether. I didn't expect history to be remembered across sessions and I believe this is not a "loss of work" scenario, although it's admittedly a nice feature. Sublime Text doesn't preserve history after closing the window, but you might argue that our users are already familiar with this behavior.
2. Add an option to preserve history. The default would be false, and users can decide to opt-in if they want to keep the original behavior.
3. Incrementally serialize history's state. This might be a nice improvement for long-running editor sessions, because we just have to serialize new changes as they come in, avoiding the repeated work of serializing the same state over and over and spreading the cost over a large timespan. This won't help the multi-cursor scenario, though, where a huge amount of changes could be collected over a short amount of time, and hence slow down the UI.
4. Serialize state across multiple `requestIdleCallback`s. This is a nice idea in theory because it allows to split the cost of serialization in `50ms` chunks, thus not blocking the main thread at all. In practice, however, it might be difficult to both keep track of changes and serialize stuff in parallel: for example, what happens if, while serializing state, an edit occurred?
5. After :ship:ping web workers, move this work off the main thread. I think @nathansobo brought up this idea in the past, but basically we could have a separate `TextBuffer` instance working on another thread; as changes come in, we `postMessage` to the worker thread and we let it deal with all the serialization stuff. This somewhat depends on structured clone being fast, though, because otherwise sending message to the worker thread would let the main thread pay roughly the same cost of serialization.

I believe 2) could actually be fine because it would allows us to keep this code path fast without sacrificing simpleness.
#### Conclusion

I think it might okay to :ship: and experiment with this even if we do not solve the problem illustrated above. If serialization is still a bottleneck after test-driving this, we definitely need to back the feature out and address the problem from another, more performant perspective.

What do you think?

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: Incorrect font rendering in the Editor view in recent versions (OS X)
data.body:
### Description

On recent versions of Atom (including 1.5.3, 1.7.0 (master)), I have noticed that there seem to be some issues with rendering text in the Editor view.

However, I discovered that this does not affect _every_ view. The autocomplete pop-over seems to have correct rendering.

As an example, see the attached images:
![atom_170_fontrenderingosx](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7536168/13206824/187300b4-d8c3-11e5-90da-f7bb80ac4c4f.png)

Enlarged, with some more noticeable differences called out:
![atom_170_fontrenderingosxenlarged](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7536168/13206835/41ca7870-d8c3-11e5-8c1b-da7a9fd44d2e.png)
_on the Issue page this ends up being resized due to its width; I recommend clicking on the image for the fullsize view which will prevent any resampling)_

(disclaimer: this scenario was captured while I had `-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased` applied on `.editor`, but this scenario also occurs in the absence of such setting)

This issue is not present in older versions of Atom; the only alternate version I currently have installed is 1.0.19. In that version, all rendering looks the same as the popover in the above images (aka, correct).
### Prerequisites

When attempting to reproduce this issue, it may help to use a font that is designed to fit nicely into pixel space when rendered at certain sizes. The one I am using is a variation of ProFontWindows, at 11px.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open the editor
2. Begin typing so that the auto-complete popover shows
3. Compare rendering of the Editor view with the popover.

**Expected behavior:** Correct rendering.

**Actual behavior:** Incorrect rendering. The rendered shapes appear to be horizontally shifted or squished to the left.
### Versions

`atom --version`

```
Atom    : 1.7.0-dev-e39d200
Electron: 0.36.7
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

`apm --version`

```
apm  1.6.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 1.8.4
```

data.title: Add support for keybindings with keyup keystrokes
data.body:
The main utility is to unblock MRU tabs: https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10737, but there should be some interesting features unlocked by this change.

Effectively, this adds new syntax for dispatching commands on keyup events. It looks like this:

``` coffee
'atom-workspace':
  'ctrl-y ^ctrl': 'core:do-stuff'
```

Which means, user presses `ctrl-y`, then lifts `ctrl` to fire the `core:do-stuff` command. If any other keybinding is used instead of a `ctrl` keyup after the `ctrl-y`, the command will not be dispatched.

For more info see the PRs on atom-keymaps
- [Add handlers for keyup events](https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/issues/113)
- [Run exact matches when the remainder of the partially matched commands are only keyup events](https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/issues/115)

cc @natalieogle

data.title: Tab Switching Performance Unacceptably Slow
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Tab performance is unacceptably slow. The issue might be masked on top of the line computers, but on my average (new Macbook 12") it is far too slow. I've performed some profiling and have pasted some screenshots of that profiling. Even with raw text files (no syntax highlighting), at least 62ms is spent purely in JS and DOM manipulation, layout and compositing. I see several forced layouts (one of which takes `13ms` by itself). 
But if those changes happen to end right at the tail end of screen display vsync, that could incur as much as another `16ms` to the latency totaling at least `78ms` (assuming I have a 60hz display). (On average it will be an additional `8ms` though).

This alone is beyond the threshold of human perceivable delay, but then these changes still take time to go from the graphics system to my display, and doesn't account for my keystroke from USB keyboard to the Atom process itself, so the total effect might be as much as `100ms` delay. I'll admit, even though I can only measure about `70ms` of delay, it _feels_ slower than that - so a large effect here might be attributed to something in the Electron/application infrastructure that escapes our measurement.
### Steps to Reproduce

(The file navigation tree is open fwiw)
1. [Open several files]
2. [Switch Tabs]
3. [experience slowness]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Fast Tab Switching.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Slow Tab Switching.
### Versions

1.5.3 Running Atom in `--safe` mode

data.title: Atom hangs and uses 100% when saving a large file for the first time
data.body:
### Description

After pasting a large block of text (160000 very short lines of XML in this case) into a new tab in Atom and trying to save, Atom hangs and uses 100% CPU.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Copy a large block of text into the clipboard.
2. Open a new tab in Atom.
3. Paste the text. Per #10855 Atom freezes for ~30s while pasting.
4. Choose the Save menu option.
5. Pick filename `foo.xml` and Save.

**Expected behavior:** Atom writes the file immediately.

**Actual behavior:** Atom freezes forever and uses 100% CPU
### Versions

Atom 1.5.3 safe mode on OS X.11 x86_64
